I think explaining what we learn from this paper that we didn't know before is helpful (and this can be as simple as rehashing what the authors themselves write). Projecting what impact the paper will have on the literature/field can also help understand the contribution.

Reviewers can easily disagree about whether a contribution is sufficient for a particular paper, so explaining a paper's contribution (or lack thereof) is crucial for navigating reviewer disagreements.

Today's econ thought: when you tell an editor that an article you're reviewing is/is not making an important contribution, it's crucial to explain why (or why not). The contribution of a paper outside one's field can be one of the hardest things for an editor to evaluate.

PSA: when writing referee reports, number your comments! Makes it easier for the editor to refer to them in decision letters ("see Comment #3 from R2"). Also makes it easier for authors when responding to those comments in their revision.

Biggest mistake made in paper introductions (in my opinion): describing how your work differs from the previous literature (e.g., "we consider a different outcome") instead of how it ADDS to the previous literature (e.g., "we show that X and Y are important determinants of Z").

Olena and Anatolii spearheaded these initiatives and are now starting their own foundation to continue and expand the work. They are lifelong Sumy residents and know what the city needs. Please donate to support their foundation! 

secure.wayforpay.com/donate/d60c0...

We've also facilitated the delivery of essential medicines to those facing financial constraints, distributed New Year's gifts to children in Sumy, supported online English lessons, and engaged in various other initiatives to make a positive impact. 
econ4ua.org/gallery-econ...

Towards the end of 2022, Russia escalated infrastructure attacks, severely disrupting schooling, including remote learning. In collaboration with Economists for Ukraine and AI for Good, Olena and Anatolii set up a secure learning environment equipped with a generator and Starlink internet.

Collaboratively, we fundraised to provide direct assistance to vulnerable residents of Sumy, distributing support in increments of around $80. Our efforts extended aid to wounded soldiers, those whose homes were damaged by Russian attacks, and those left unemployed. deryugina.com/fundraiser-f...

Almost immediately after the war began, Olena and her husband Anatolii took it upon themselves to help others. I encouraged them to leave, telling him how generous people were toward fleeing Ukrainians. They asked: "How can we bring that same generosity to those who remain in Sumy?"

Olena lives in Sumy, Ukraine, a city that’s just 30 kilometers from the Russian border. It was one of the first to be attacked on February 24, 2022, and escaped occupation only thanks to the courage of its residents. 

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian...

Want to help Ukrainians living near the front lines? Support the impactful work of my cousin Olena’s charity, Best Friends.

I elaborate on these thoughts in the blog + link to previous relevant blog posts I've written in the past. Enjoy!
That said, people you cite in the introduction are more likely to be asked to review your paper, so you want to put some thought into that. But don't omit cites that belong there!

There’s a good chance your reviewer will not be who you think it is. Trying to guess who it will be (or who it was) and tailor your paper to them in some way is not a good use of your time in most cases.
When reviewing, your reasoning matters much more than your recommendation. Don't sweat the recommendation, just focus on explaining the strengths and weaknesses of the paper.
The editorial process is not a democracy where majority rules. Reviewer recommendations (positive or negative) are not binding.

Luckily, it's not too late to change course. Western leaders must act quickly to provide Ukraine with what it needs. Delays only help Russia.

In many cases, Ukraine waited for over a year before getting the military aid it requested, while Russia was advancing and building up defenses. Those defenses now make it much harder for Ukraine to advance.

In this op-ed, Anastassia Fedyk, Alex Richter, and I show how severe delays in providing weapons to Ukraine have been and how these delays are now making it harder for Ukraine to take back its land.

New working paper: @@514 and I estimate that a permanent, 10% reduction in air pollution exposure would raise life expectancy by about 1.2 years.

There's a lot more in the paper (model + calibration details, other pollutants, etc). We hope this helps bridge the gap between obtaining well-identified short-run estimates and knowing the effects of chronic exposure.
Even though the increased exposure begins at birth, most survival benefits accrue to older people because that's when extra health capital is particularly valuable.

Finally, we use the calibrated model to project the effects on survival of a permanent, 1-unit reduction in SO2. The implied survival benefits are large and substantially larger than a naive scaling of the IV estimates.

We then calibrate a dynamic mortality model developed by Lleras-Muney and Moreau (2022) that captures age-specific mortality responses in our data and the presence of mortality displacement. The model performs really well in-sample.

We also show the presence of both mortality displacement (SO2 killing really frail people) and "accelerated aging" (SO2 killing people with a delay). Total cancer deaths increase initially but fall to zero after about two weeks. Cardio and other deaths grow over time.

First, we estimate the effect of acute (one-day) SO2 exposure on mortality 1-28 days following exposure, using wind direction as the instrument for SO2. Even over this time period, total mortality continues increasing after exposure ends, indicating that dynamics are important.

Finding exogenous variation in chronic exposure is really hard, not least because we know people sort on air pollution exposure. So we propose a different way that leverages short-run quasi-experimental variation + a structural model of health.

First, why even ask this instead of estimating effects of chronic exposure directly? TL;DR: researchers have been trying for a long time and all we have to show for it is a handful of quasi-experimental papers (and many non-experimental ones that probably suffer from bias).

New working paper alert!

@@268166 and I tackle the question of "What can we learn about the effects of chronic pollution exposure from shorter-run estimates?"

www.nber.org/papers/w31858

Decisions about accepted papers will be made by mid-November. Complete drafts of papers will be due in April 2024. Papers are reviewed by editors only (Matt Kotchen, Catherine Wolfram, and me). The authors of each paper will share an $8,000 honorarium.
Submissions should be either 2-3 page abstracts outlining the intended contribution, or a complete paper this is not and will not be submitted for publication elsewhere.

Papers should be relevant to current policy debates and accessible to a professional audience. Standalone projects are encouraged, but we also welcome spinoff projects where authors intend to later submit a more extensive/technical version to a journal, or have already done so.
You can browse past EEPE volumes at the following link: www.journals.uchicago.edu/loi/eepe

What is it? EEPE is a unique annual volume aimed at highly policy-relevant papers. Chosen papers will be presented on May 23, 2024 at the National Press Club in Washington, D.C. Lots of people working in government (as well as academics) attend.

Quick @@4138327 tip: you can add opacity to your graph by adding "%X" after the color, where 0≤X≤100:

sysuse sp500, clear
replace high = high+80
twoway (hist high, width(20) color(blue%50)) (hist low, width(20) color(red%50)), scheme(s1mono) legend(order(1 "Blue" 2 "Red"))
